conversation.content: [quietly] Seven years, Marcus. Seven years I've been tracking you across three continents, and here you are in a hospice bed looking like death already claimed half of you.
[warm] Hello, Jackson. [coughs] I wondered if you'd make it before the cancer finished its work. Please, sit down, there's a chair by the window with a decent view of the garden.
[confused] You knew I was coming? [pause] The bounty on your head is two million dollars, and you're just lying there offering me a seat like we're old friends catching up.
[very sincerely] We were friends once, before everything went wrong. [shaky voice] I've been expecting you for months now, kept telling the nurses someone important would visit before the end.
[bitter] Friends don't sell out their unit to enemy forces. [frustrated] Fourteen good soldiers died because of your intel, Marcus, fourteen families destroyed because you wanted a payday.
[regretful] It wasn't about money, Jackson, though I know that's what everyone believes. [sighs] They had my daughter, threatened to sell her to traffickers if I didn't give them the patrol routes.
[stunned] Your daughter? [long pause] You never mentioned having a kid, not once in all those years we served together, all those nights playing cards in the barracks.
[very quietly] Her mother never told me until she was dying herself, begged me to protect our little girl. [clearing throat] I had exactly three weeks with her before they took her.
[hesitantly] So you traded fourteen lives for one? That's your justification for becoming the most wanted traitor in military history, for making me spend seven years hunting you?
[exhausted] I traded everything for her. [coughs] My honor, my friends, my soul.
[conflicted] Where is she now, this daughter you burned the world down to save? Did she even survive whatever deal you made with those monsters?
[smiling speaking] She's a doctor now, working in refugee camps near the Syrian border. [warmly] Goes by her mother's name, doesn't know anything about me or what I did.
[angry] You think that makes it right? [speeding up] Those fourteen soldiers had children too, had lives and futures that you stole from them with one encrypted message.
I think about them every single day, Jackson. Their names are carved into my memory deeper than this disease eating through my bones.
[coldly] The bounty says dead or alive, you know. [pause] Most hunters would have put a bullet in you from the doorway, collected their money, and been done with it.
[peacefully] But you're not most hunters, are you? [coughs] You came here for answers, not just for the money, because you need to understand why I did it.
[very quietly] I need to know if any part of the man I called brother is still in there.
[trembling] He died the moment I sent that message, but he wanted you to know he was sorry. [trailing off] God, Jackson, I've been so sorry for so long...
[resigned] The official report will say you died of natural causes before I arrived. [slowly] The bounty can rot in hell along with everything else from that war.
[relieved] Thank you, brother. [very softly] Will you stay, just until the morphine takes me under again? I don't want to face the darkness alone anymore. [pause] Please.

scenario: A bounty hunter finally corners the traitor who sold out their shared military unit years ago, only to discover they're dying from a terminal illness.
